ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Weekly recorded lecture
2x weekly virtual seminar, 1x weekly recorded lecture
Weekly lecture and reading questions.
Weekly lecture accompanied two seminars.
none
Seminar discussion were surrounding pre-recorded weekly lectures.
Weekly lectures posted on the courses' relevant reading.
Recorded lecture

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed reading and writing skills, as well as language to discuss political philosophy

I learned more about the Ancient Greek and Roman historians and political thinkers and the steps need to write a paper that closely analyzes a passage and explains the implication of the passage in terms of the whole text and the author's ideas.

My close reading skills improved immensely, along with my ability to construct organized and coherent arguments and convincing papers. The class equipped me to think about history and politics in a more complex and thought-through way, and to question my assumptions about history and politics.
I learned how to critically think about both historys great and nuanced pieces, placing them in their time periods and understanding them both conceptually and relatively.

How to evaluate a text by isolating certain pieces and analyzing them. I learned how to draw connections throughout early historical and political thought and how to evaluate history told from a perspective and during a time that was relatively new to me.

By taking this course, I developed the ability to read historical texts in-depth for their themes. These themes were then able to be analyzed across the curriculum to find overarching ideas that have developed throughout antiquity. Finally, I was able to gain knowledge of how most information and political systems change throughout time.
Analysis of political theory

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course, more so than the other two DS courses, seemed to have more "filler" information in the readings that we were assigned but never really talked about in discussion. I wish we could have more specific sections to read and focus on, so that I could spend less time reading and get more from the texts.

This course has a very high reading load which was stressful. I am a slow reader which meant I often didn't finish readings and was then less involved in discussions than I wanted to be. But when I had finished the reading and was fully engaged, I found our discussion questions fascinating

Lectures were generally good, but many could have used more general information and scaffolding. With all of the close reading, it is easy to lose the big-picture and providing that in lectures would have helped. Professor Schillinger's introductions served this purpose well. 
Strengths: a supportive but challenging seminar environment with rigorous discussion, smart and passionate peers, and amazing texts.
Like any DS course, too many books and not enough time spent on them, but this is the general goal with DS so its acceptable. More clear essay guild lines would be cool.

I think going virtual stood as a huge impediment to my learning experience. It could not be helped, of course, but I would hope that when covid ended there would be a huge emphasis on the in person elements.

The strengths of this course were in its ability to transition easily to an online format. Seminars felt personal and engaging. The readings, which would have been done personally even during a traditional year, were fascinating and wonderful texts.
The small class size and seminar format was perfect.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was comfortable with the virtual seminar format; I feel like we still had good discussions
Holding office hours weekly through a doodle poll helped.
All of them succeeded.

I think the lectures were very much disengaging because they were prerecorded. Maybe doing it in a setting where the lecturer could be speaking live in camera would be more beneficial so that students can truly engage by asking questions and simulating a real class environment.
Again, the small class size ensured engagement from the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, even if they don't think they would necessarily be interested in ancient history and/or politics. I was not expecting to enjoy this class as much as I did, mostly because I didn't even understand what "Historical & Political Thought" meant. Give it a try! It's great.
Yes, I would recommend the whole DS programthe major drawback is the super heavy reading load

Wholeheartedly. H and P is a delightful and enlightening class. Be sure to engage with the texts as much as possible, because otherwise, one will not see or understand the recurring problems and themes that rise out of the tradition of thought we study.
Yes, I think DS gives a historical background to tons of content and everyone should know it.

To someone considering taking this class I would say to be aware that the co tent and discussions are 90% based in an ancient times and there are not a lot of chances to make modern day connections. Of course there is a richness of discussions that can be had about those times and those ancient writers but if you were looking for a class that would emphasize connecting the past to the future there is not much of that in this class.

I would strongly recommend this course to another student. The course fosters a great sense intellectual curiosity in students and grants first years a unique ability to write personally engaging papers on relevant topics. Although the readings may be of a higher level than students have experienced before, it is well worth the challenge.

If they are interested in a discussion about politics that goes even deeper than simple political theory, then yes. The insertion of morality, religion, and philosophy into our discussion of political thought made the class challenging and interesting.
